147378719.review:
[h2] TL;DR It has promise, but in its current state I wouldn't recommend playing this for more than a few hours. [/h2]

The assets [u]heavily[/u] borrow from the My Hero Fighting Game, which are vibrant and fun (especially if you're a fan of the anime) meaning you can pick up one of the hero's / villains you love most in the show and use their iconic abilities. The skeleton/ framework of the game feels to me like a near copy of the Naruto: Shinobi Striker game. So this is a mashup of those two [b] with all of the pro's and con's of both [/b].

The abilities look and feel powerful for most characters, meaning you can hop back and forth between different characters and mess around with play styles. I've enjoyed the speed based characters the most (Ochaco, Froppy and Ida) as they feel the most unique in using terrain to their advantage. 

Although the abilities look wonderful in the cell shaded style they feel quite heavy and can take up a lot of the screen leading you to easily get yourself lost in a fight with another team. In addition. you'll find that if you've had your shield broken by two abilities/ attacks that you'll be getting knocked over constantly. The evade window works in a 1v1 setting, but, in this 3v3 game-mode dodging (using Ctrl as default) feels absolutely pointless. 

Menu-ing is atrocious, honestly some of the worst I've seen in a multiplayer game, it feels un-intuitive and screens are never as easy to access as you'd like. Why can't you unlock characters in the shop, why do some menu icons feel like they need to be clicked twice to access and why is readying up in a small box to the left instead of underneath your character?

Monetisation what you can expect from a standard free-to-play gacha game. I've counted 4 main currencies as well as 3 others that unlock items in the "gallery"? Horrible way to pad out timed challenges and battle passes. On top of this, [b] locking characters behind a paywall [/b] will inevitably lead to a toxic Pay2Win environment with some characters being stronger than others, regardless of skill. 

The devs have counteracted this by giving new users access to one character ticket to unlock whoever you'd like which is a good start, but I doubt it'll help the longevity of the game.  

[h3] Here's what I'd like to see improved [/h3]
- Abilities being on a decent cool down leading to fights needing to rely more on melee and the dodge mechanic
- Much simpler menu's 
- More Game mode's (including solo and team based objectives)
- Revive's easier to collect (one ticket rather than three) but are more visible and longer to cast.
- Plus Ultra having a kind of Ultimate/ Super attack as at the minute it feels lack luster
- Objectives other than box opening and rescuing 

A Solid 5/10, will keep my eye on it over the coming months.

I recommend it all the way. At the time of writing this I have about 30 hours in the game.

147365890.review:
At the moment,  I have over 30 hours into the game.

The grind is really not that bad. I got Toga, Compress, gundam speed boy, Bakugo, and vine girl within 12 hours of play. The game gives you a lot of crystals at the start that you can dump into leveling up the special licence which really helps out. They give you 4 free ten pulls at the start. And if you create a agency or join one. You can level up your gym and get crazyyyy exp boosts that also help with leveling your special licence to unlock characters faster. I am already at level 32 and have cleared most of the event rewards, completed all the weekly, etc. 2 - 3 games a day finishes all your dailies. And yes, you can also test out characters you want to play before unlocking them. A lot of the free choices are really nice. Especially Dabi who I have won countless games with now. ITS NOT THAT BAD.

Negatives:

- Rewards for challenges are dog shit. You get like.. 3 pulls a week from doing them. Gotcha games on mobile have better drops than that.
- The skins in this game are dog shit. If you want us to spend money to keep this game up. Make some better skins besides recolors that look like they belong in the 90s. I am a 3d artist, so I know texture editing is really simple. Charging people for texture edits is ludicrous. 
- Lower the pity rate. 200 pulls for a pity is rough when the diamond rate is so terribly low and most people, like me, use those beginner diamonds to level up their special licence to unlock meta characters instead of wasting them on a banner with 3 mediocre characters. Put it at 100. 
- Can't bend over emote with mount lady in giant form. Smh
- Player base on PC is dwindling. The first day, it was really fast to find and play a match. Now it takes at least 10 minutes to load in. Compress your servers. Having too many is causing the connection errors we are having and the maintenance from yesterday. Too many is making things take too long and breaking shit.
- Maps are really small and the circle moves way too fast. Increase the map size, make new maps, or at least cut the time on the circle by at least 30%.

But at the end of the day, the game has only been out for 2 days. ITS REALLY FUN FOR WHAT IT IS. Stick with it and I am sure it'll get better.

147364667.review:
I've played for around 2 days now, and I'm ready for a quick little review.

Character unlocks - Though 3 of the characters are unlocked via rolling, the better characters are unlocked in the Special License tab, which is completely free, though it's seems abit long, most games will give 4-5k points if you play well, Deku is the starter character and is one of the best, and the first 2 unlocks within this tab are the most powerful. From rolling you can get 3 characters, They're all great but easily replaceable by their early game counterparts.

Visuals - Wasn't expecting alot since this game was built up from used assests, but for a F2P game, It looks quite good, some of the animations can be wonky but I can't complain. Hopefully they'll add a new map for rotation sometime in the future since the current one can get quite repetitive.

Gameplay - Very team-based, It's nearly impossible to beat a team of 3 without your own team, The role system is something that I could still try messing with more due to the effects stacking, such as +3 Rapid buffs. The spawning system isn't bad and I like the simplicity of it, could do with a ground format for inner structures instead of spawning through holes. The looting is nearly perfect in my opinion, And the Mega boxes that drop are definitely a game changer, I wish there was a bonus for when you picked up your own character's ability card, like an extra upgrade, but I can't complain. Zones are a staple in every battle royal and this game does them decently well, and I can imagine some future characters interacting with it in some ways that are unique. I think the Down state is done well, and they clearly thought about the Team focus alot more then other Battle royals, the abilities linked to reviving are a good idea but the it's not really unique, all of them involve a barrier covering the enemy or moving them, I'd like to see a revive where it restores shield or upgrades abilities.

Combat - Most of the time, I forget I have a basic combo string. You always have a move off CD, and in the later games, why would you do a basic combo when you have 3 maxed out abilities to spam? And there's barely any benefit to comboing since barely any characters have combo string, best example being Lida, but even then his combos are wonky and barely work. The current meta characters are all strong due to their Strong range spam moves, like Deku and Bakugo which decreases the usability of characters with no way to fight them, Kendo has been redundant since her release due to her lack of range and her almost useless Special ability, I do think the Combat is fun, just not fair.

Conclusion - It's F2P, get it and see for yourself.

147335176.review:
The actual gameplay's a bit janky and not terribly well balanced at the moment, but reasonably fun. I think it far outperforms the average battle royal on that front, just by virtue of of the hero shooter/MOBA-like character design & format adding a lot of texture to how fights play out.

But wow the economy is awful. Totally ignoring the poor F2P earn rate, there's several currencies I literally don't know where in the client to spend them. If you want to pay money to unlock a character, you can't really, you have to filter it through like three sub currencies before eventually getting gatcha tickets that convert into two other currencies that are what you use to buy characters, and one of those routes is like 30% less efficient than the other for no reason. It's worse than mobile games I've seen which is wild. Like there's a difference between "Obtuse to conceptually separate game currencies and real money" and "Outright confusing and difficult to interact with". I get why a game might have miserable F2P progression, but there's no reason it should be so bizarrely difficult to pay money to unlock a specific character.

I'm hoping they just gut the economy entirely and replace it something that's less of a mess, it's a drag that such a good idea for a game is bogged down by a horrendous rats nest of an economy, I don't think I can recommend it while it's in this state.

147330229.review:
Honestly, a refreshing battle royale, and it isn't an absolute pain to learn, you won't get demolished by people who have spent several hours more, but there is a reason for it:

[b] Balancing. [/b]

i do enjoy this game and can recommend it, but my god is the balancing terrible, some characters have moves that can quite literally hit people from different areas of the map, Bakugo's "Beta" move (they used the greek alphabet for the abilities for some reason, idk why) is quite literally a bomb that can be thrown a horrendous distance, and his "Alpha" move is quite shocking as it's a beam that can almost instantly hit people from quite far.

characters like this with ranged abilities, especially ones with a mix of range and movement are horrendously unfair, a Deku can squad wipe by just using his "Alpha" move, which has 10 shots at max level, and does 100 damage per shot, 250 shield and about 350 health on each person means that if you have somewhat mediocre co-ordination with a Bakugo, you can quite literally instantly down people before they can even react sometimes, I'm guilty of doing this, it's honestly quite the cheese.

some characters feel useless, and seeing them on your team or on enemy team just means free wins, as of writing this, I'm yet to see a Mr. Compression or toga in game, purely because no one wants to play characters with somewhat harder to use kits, when they can just range attack and win, the top 50 players all either use deku, todoroki or bakugo because of this.

not a bad game, but some changes are most definitely needed.

147324814.review:
5/10

I have certainly played worse but my god this game is jank as heck. First off, for a game that incorporates third-person shooting mechanics, the FOV is so zoomed in on your character that it's hard to aim but even harder to tell where the heck you're being shot at from. The hitboxes are bad, I'll watch shots from me and teammates go right through someone completely and get no damage but they'll do an area of effect move that I'm way out of reach for and still, I somehow get hit. 

I'm not sure if it would've been balanced because of all of the character ability differences but it sucks that there's no duos or solo-play mode and that its always got to be teams of three, matchmaking takes forever, and then when I load in I am usually the first one to die while my teammates are literally standing next to me at full health and guard points and either do nothing or start to run away. Maybe the experience could be a little bit better if I had two friends to party with consistently and have voice chat communication but it's hard to convince a friend to play this when the game play is so bad.

The menus are so confusing that I have no idea what is going on, I notice in the character select menu some characters have a lock symbol and say to use them you have to use this little card emblem thing which it says I have 3/3 of but it doesn't explain what that emblem is? Is it limited? Can I get more of it? Does it refresh every day back to 3 or maybe every few hours? and if I use one does that unlock that character permanently or just for that single game? I never seen anything that explains this. Some people said the characters were locked behind loot boxes I went through all the menus and couldn't even see anywhere to purchase them so at this point I don't even know.

This game is just meh, not saying it can't be enjoyed to some degree, but it's worse than Jump Force so I'm about certain that if Bandai canned the servers for that so soon, then this will probably be no different at that rate.

147317803.review:
This game needs to rework its hero system and fast. You should not have to roll a loot box in order to get characters, or lock heroes in a battle pass! These should be cosmetic things only, such as costumes and etc, not actual heroes. Though, given how most of the costumes are just recolors ( including the ones in the battle pass, which is also just another bad call on there part. Make these items worth my money), I doubt they have the team behind them generate the cosmetics needed to get funding so they paywall the characters we know and love. 

This game should base itself off of other hero based titles such as League of Legends, Overwatch, Dead by Daylight to name a few. All these games have lots of characters with unique abilities that will lure people in every patch to check out the new stuff. These characters can all be obtained with in-game currency or premium which people will shell out if they are just jumping in quick, but be rewarding to those long lasting players. 

The heroes is the biggest negative to me, just be good to your player base and they'll be good to you. But the heroes, alongside the stale map and lack of game modes at the moment, this game needs a bit more time to figure itself out and focus on making a good game instead of a cash grab.

Battle pass has been the worst idea to plague modern gaming. Why am I paying money to have to work to unlock the things I paid for? I'm a grown adult and I don't have the time to do all this. Either give me the stuff or don't. Devs are just worried people aren't going to spend the true price they want them to pay, money or time. I feel like my time is worth more than some random collectible in a video game. I thought this would be a fun distraction, but it turned into another point in a future manifesto.

147312636.review:
This game is strange. Its a mix of a fighting game and a battle royale, only it sucks at both.
The fighting aspect is horrendous, every combo being dropped after 1 ability or 3 regular hits. Opponents are immune for a brief period which renders you unable to do anything. It makes the combat feel very clunky as you often have to stop in the middle of combat and wait for the immune period to wear off. 
As for the battle royale part, it is far from better. The map is extremely small, and a couple of characters are able to hit you from a pretty good distance making some of the cast much better than others (Bakugo). Also, the down mechanics are kinda clunky. Now this might be a bit of a skill issue, as I might have missed an item, but sometimes people get rezzed without anything or anyone being near them. For example, I was fighting a team and knocked down 1. The other 2 were on me and all of a sudden, the guy that was knocked out comes back to fight me. How he could come back still eludes me.
Lastly, the balancing of this game seems all over the place, as some characters feel wildly overpowered compared to others. While some have no movement abilities or range, Bakugo has one of the highest ranged attack with a very high amount of damage and 2 movement abilities, which makes fighting him extremely unfair. This is only one example of questionable balancing.
All in all, this game is neither a good fighting game nor a good br, making it very mediocre. You should really only play this if you are a fan of the anime.

147294954.review:
This game has a lot of room for potential, but as it is at base release, is SUPER FUN. 

Each character supports a unique playstyle, that gives you the chance to find the person you have most fun playing, and providing ample strategy from how you fight, which items you use, where you spawn and how you coordinate with a team.
   This is not a game you'd play nonstop for months, as there's only one map, and it'd likely get repetitive after a bit. But there's still many hours of fun to have, and a good time with friends nonetheless.
   My personal favorite part of the game is that some characters have unique moves that add to their mobility, like Bakugo having air explosions, Ururaka's m1 being a wire that can be used to hook to buildings, or Deku's black whip skill also hooking to buildings.

All in all, there's a handful that can be added to increase the variety of the game, but as it is now is still super fun and rewarding for learning your character and the game's ins and outs. 

Beware of gacha grind.

Reminds me of Fortnite, love it for the nostalgia. Here are my takeaways:

Cons
Needs more than 1 map and they should be bigger.
It's nearly impossible to find a single revive card throughout the match.
The rolls and pt feature to unlock new players is tedious and very expensive.

Pros
Looks good and I enjoy the combat system.
There's an EXP system you earn each match that can unlock new characters faster.
It's a very unique BR with no guns which is refreshing. 
The matches are very challenging so it keeps me engaged and interested. 

Overall an awesome game, I have my critiques but other than the revival cards my criticisms don't affect the actual game play. People are leaving bad reviews over the expensive point system to unlock characters, but the game is free and the devs need to profit somehow so I get it. You can get points slowly through a lot of game play if you do not wish to pay anything, there's also an experience point system that allows you to unlock characters faster.

147273962.review:
My Hero Ultra Rumble: A Bumpy Start 🎮
Hey, gamer pals! Interested in My Hero Ultra Rumble? Let's get into it.

Controls: More Tangled Than Froppy's Tongue 🎮
Trust me, the controls will leave you more tangled than Froppy's tongue. 🐸 It's not the seamless experience you'd hope for in an action-packed game.

Gacha: Not a Fan 🎰
Cosmetics are hidden behind a Gacha system. While it's not affecting gameplay, I'm not thrilled about it. It's like Mineta's sticky balls—some people might like them, but they're not for everyone. 🍇

Bag & Menus: Quite the Puzzle 🎒
Grabbing items in the heat of a match? Good luck. Your bag fills up and suddenly you're fumbling through confusing menus. It's a hassle, especially when you need to level up your skills on the fly.

Late-Game Revival? Just Don't 🚑
Reviving late feels pointless; you lose all your power-ups. It's like Endeavor trying to win a "Father of the Year" award—better not to even go there. 🔥

Unlocking Heroes? Hold Your Horses 🦸‍♂️
Excited to play as your favorite hero? Well, you'll have to wait; unlocking characters isn't an option yet.

My Two Cents 🤔
I want to love this game, but for now, it's a "hold off" from me. Hoping for improvements!

What do you think? Agree or disagree? Let me know below! 🗨️

Till next time! 🎮✌️

147272944.review:
The concept is pretty great and fitting for MHA, and the core gameplay feels mostly fine aside from some wonky balancing, but there are some major issues of course...

First, no crossplay is going to kill this game FAST on PC, even if the game is F2P.  Crossplay should be standard for multiplatform competitive games these days, especially for something that's clearly taking a lot of inspiration from other battle royale games, most of which have crossplay.

Second, a lot of characters are locked, some behind gacha (With the option to unlock them for special credits that you get through duplicates), and some behind a VERY grindy battle pass (Albeit, a free one separate from the normal battle pass) that levels up super slowly and still has filler rewards between character unlocks.  You *do* get some free rental tickets that can be used to play any locked character for a single match, but if you're playing a lot that's obviously nothing.

I think the game definitely has potential assuming they have regular content/balancing updates, but it needs crossplay ASAP if it wants to even survive and thrive for a full year, and locking playable characters should ideally be removed.  Or hell, at least just allow people to directly purchase individual characters (For a FAIR price, that is, not some outlandish price geared towards whales and obscured behind 50 different in-game currencies).

Projectile characters feel very overpowering against characters without projectiles of their own as you can literally just hit and run. This is definitely frustrating to be on the receiving end of this. 

My only problems are there is no clear explanation on how to get new character, if a character can't be bought with a ticket I feel like the game should direct you to where you could get them ie the gacha system or BP.

The currency feels heavily inflated especially when most of us played my heros justice 1 or 2 and would basically be repaying way more for the skins we used to have.
My only negatives with this game is that I wish more effort was put into the cosmetics as that is what will basically what will be keeping this game alive apart from that the mechanics are solid and I hope they're able to experiment with new ideas in future can't wait to see what they've got planned 

Tldr: short q's, cosmetics feel quite plain, very fun gameplay, projectiles are frustrating without any,not enough maps.HOW DO WE UNLOCK NEW CHAR?!?!?. Gacha is no fun when it's all in one loot pool.

147268533.review:
I really am on the fringe of not recommending this one, it's current review score of mixed is very fitting in all honesty. The heroes and outfits work off a gatcha and loot box system, however as an Overwatch 2 player I'm used to worst abuse so I'd much rather the system in place than having to spend 19 dollars on a hero. I can see this game improving over time though, as many of my issues are with early release bugs and missing features that can be easily implemented.

The Good:
- Fun gameplay
- A unique spin on the BR genre
- Matches are generally quick so if you lose, it doesn't feel as frustrating
- Characters and abilities that are very on par with that of the show and source material.

The Bad:
- Constant Unity crashes, I think I must have crashed 5 or 6 different times when I played.
- SO many forms of currency
- Terrible UI, the "Leave game" option is called "Results" at the end of a match and it can be very. very confusing to find things in the main menu.
- No push to talk so most people turn off voice chat as it's constant open mic, really bad for a team based game
- Ridiculous censoring in text chat when the source material uses worst. Really. The word/non-word "uhoh" you can't say. It makes it even more confusing when characters like Dabi will say "Damn it" when hurt or in a fight, yet you can't say it in the text chat.

Overall, it's not a bad game and it's free so it's worth a try at least. When you start the game it will load you down with in game currency and ticket pulls (the games version of loot boxes), however this is very common for gatcha games to get you in the door so I'm not really counting that as a plus for the game as much as I appreciate it. The downside is some of these characters are locked behind the gatcha system and the odds of getting them are around 0.5% each. Some people have brought up balancing issues, however once you learn each characters play style it's not as unbalanced as it's made out to be. Some characters excel in close range, others long range. I can see the developers intention of working with your teammates to pick up the weaknesses of each other however as stated previously, communication is almost impossible due to the bad voice chat system in the game so it makes this almost impossible to do with randoms.

Edit: I do see a lot of people bringing up the monetization and at the end of the day, you need to pick your poison. One's Justice one and two both died very, very quickly as you had to pay for the game and anime based games aren't very popular in the first place so it makes sense why this game would be a free to play. Granted, I do wish there was a 60 dollar DLC option to just buy everything in the game, however the game still needs to make money somehow while still being available for a lot of people to play to keep it alive. This may be me speaking from a place of good luck but I haven't spent a penny on the game and so far I've been able to get Creati, Vine, the Shigaraki coat outfit AND upgrade to the premium pass all through just playing the game and getting the in game currency. From my perspective and keep in mind this is just me, you do not need to drop a bunch of money for stuff like you would need to in a game like Genshin Impact or Honkai.

I recommend this game 100% before it dies off

I WOULD recommend the game when it is in a better state but I would not recommend it currently because new people need to be introduced to this wonderful game with a more friendly interface. 

Time to hop back in a game. PLUS ULTRA BABY!

147263758.review:
I think this is my first negative review on a game. 

Oh, where do I even begin with My Hero Ultra Fumble? It's like the developers took a masterclass in how to create a game that leaves you questioning your life choices.

Firstly, the character design is so absurd that I thought I accidentally stumbled into a Saturday morning cartoon for toddlers. I mean, who thought it was a good idea to add Cementoss over literally anyone else.
And let's talk about the controls. It's as if the game developers handed a toddler a baguette and said, "Here you go, this is your controller now." Trying to execute a combo felt more like trying to tap dance on a minefield - random and explosive.

The in-game physics deserve an award for their commitment to chaos. I witnessed my hero soaring through the air like a majestic, slightly constipated eagle. The laws of gravity and common sense were mere suggestions in this digital disaster.

Oh, and let's not forget the sound effects. Every punch and kick sounds like a wet sponge hitting a brick wall. It's the kind of audio experience that makes you question whether you accidentally stepped on the cat or if it's just the game being its charming self.

In conclusion, My Hero Ultra Fumble is a masterpiece of incompetence. If you're looking for a game that will make you question your life choices and the state of the gaming industry, look no further. It's so bad that it's almost good – but not quite. Save your time, buy a real cheeseburger, and savor the taste of something that won't leave you questioning the meaning of your existence. They should be paying people to play this game, free to play is not cutting it.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

147251094.review:
This is coming from someone who hasn't really been invested in My Hero for quite awhile now, probably about 4 years? So take that into consideration as well.

The game itself is... alright. It's a battle royale, but with fun superpowers. The controls are a little jank, but I'm sure with time you could adjust to them because they're not unplayably bad. It's super fast paced, which can make it a little difficult to try and pay attention to what's happening, and where you're being attacked from. Most of my experience is from Apex, which when I last played was pretty similar to this. Less intensive on the computer though, so there's that plus.

The main, glaring issue, is the gacha system. It blows absolute chunks. It has a horrible pity system, where with 200 rolls you can guarantee yourself one of the 3 characters in the current loot rolls. I didn't do the exact math, but from eyeballing it would definitely be more than $100 for one character if you got extremely unlucky. Which, given that the loot tables show that each item that you can pull has a less than 1% chance to even be pulled, you probably won't get the character you want.
And to unlock characters, from what me and my friend could figure out (which took way too long, the currencies and how to unlock stuff isn't explained well at all) you need hero tickets, which you can get for 100 souls. Only once, mind you. Then you can get one ticket for 200 souls. Then from that point on all tickets will be 300 souls. What are souls? Duplicates from pulls on the gacha. You /might/ be able to get a handful from missions or the battle pass, but I wouldn't count on it.
But as you read yes- on top of a gacha with a horrible pity system, there is a battle pass. The free one, I will say is quite generous compared to most free tracks, but you don't get a lot of exp per game to level it. So to get the characters locked behind that as well, expect to grind a hell of a lot.

Now, gachas are pretty normal in F2P games in the past few years, and I understand some people don't mind them as much. If it was solely cosmetic, I really wouldn't mind them, but they do end up being pretty predatory no matter what. It's especially worse when whole characters, in a PVP game, are locked behind luck based pulls. And not all of the characters are created equal, either. It's almost similar to the Overwatch 2 situation, where there is competitive modes locked behind gacha and pass mechanics. Hell, even a game like Pokemon Unite pulls it off better than this game does.

There isn't even an option to purchase them out right with real money, which is really a shame. I totally would've put a few bucks in to be able to play as my fave character, Kirishima, but he's locked behind the gacha for this time around. Probably would've come back to it from time to time, because the quirks do make combat interesting, but you're given 1 free hero ticket at the time of this review, and 3 sort of "trial" tickets, where you can try out 3 different heroes, or the same hero 3 times.

If you really like My Hero, and have the money to blow for the stuff you want, then sure go for it. But if there's just one or two characters you wanna play, I'm sure the fighting game they made would probably be better suited. 

tl;dr:
mid game, insane amounts of gacha and battle pass microtransactions, has potential to be fun but characters that are better than others being locked behind paywalls is a horrible way to do shit and sours most of the experience
i had no expectations and yet it somehow failed to meet them

147251060.review:
At the time of this review I've played for 1h30 and I can already see where this game needs to improve.

The negative:

- You can't unlock characters directly, you only get 3 free game per day with locked characters, if you want to unlock them permanently, you have to spend points you get when using a roll which is basically a loot-box.
I've used about 20 rolls and I managed to get 48 points, a character costs 200 points.
My guess is that the free characters are going to change each day or week but it's frustrating.

- The fighting mechanic is very confusing, we know the anime is full of special effects every time a character attacks which they recreated here. I get that they wanted to keep the fighting style of the source material which is fine when 2 or 3 people are fighting but when you get 10 heroes or villains fighting at the same place it gets really chaotic.

- There's only one map and it is very tiny

- The items you get for free or those in the shop have no description, I bought a character ticket thinking I'd be able to unlock a hero but it doesn't seem to work that way and I still haven't figured out what it does lol

- Leveling up your hero agency (which is basically a guild) takes ages, I did about 10 games and the progress bar barely moved

The positive:

- The aesthetic of the anime is there, same for the sound effects.

- The character models are really well made and have fun costumes. Not a lot as per now but I'm sure they'll add more in the future

- Speaking about costumes, you can easily unlock a lot of them. Yes, it is a loot-box system but even if you get doubles, you get currency you can spend in the shop. Also, there's a special type of costume which has different colors of auras.
Every time you get doubles of one of those, you get access to a new aura color that you can use to customize this said outfit.

- The gameplay is simple yet varied enough to turn the tied of the battle to your advantage when the right strategy is used. That is IF you manage to understand what is happening on screen.


Overall, the game is not bad, I wouldn't recommend it in its actual state, unless you're a big fan of the anime and you're not epileptic.



Edit:
Thanks guys for explaining some things that were not clear to me.
Much appreciate it :)

I'll give it another go and see if I enjoy it more.

147249303.review:
Title: Disastrous Disappointment

Rating: ★☆☆☆☆ (1/5)

Review by: Dystopia

MY HERO ULTRA RUMBLE is a prime example of a game that had so much potential but ended up being an absolute trainwreck. I wouldn't wish this game upon my worst enemy, and I feel genuinely sorry for anyone who spent their hard-earned money on it.

Let's start with the graphics. In a world where breathtaking visuals are becoming the norm, MY HERO ULTRA RUMBLE looks like it was designed by a team of amateurs with a limited budget. Character models are bland, environments lack detail, and the animations are so stiff and lifeless that it's hard to believe this game was released in the 21st century.

The gameplay is a mess. Combat feels clunky and unresponsive, with poorly designed controls that make you want to throw your controller across the room in frustration. The hit detection is laughable, and the AI is so brain-dead that you'll wonder if you're playing against a bunch of cardboard cutouts. The game's mechanics are convoluted and poorly explained, leaving you to figure things out through trial and error.

The story is an afterthought, with a plot so generic and uninspired that it's forgettable within minutes. The voice acting is equally forgettable, with characters delivering their lines in a monotonous, emotionless fashion that drains any potential for immersion.

But perhaps the biggest insult is the microtransactions. MY HERO ULTRA RUMBLE shamelessly bombards you with in-game purchases at every turn. Want a new character? Pay up. Want a cool costume? Pay up. It's a blatant cash grab that preys on unsuspecting players.

Save your money and your sanity. Avoid MY HERO ULTRA RUMBLE at all costs. It's a disgrace to the gaming industry, and I can't believe I wasted my time on this dumpster fire of a game.

147245082.review:
A game about heroes that has villainous practices.

Costumes and heroes are locked behind gacha (which has a pity that only lasts on a per banner basis, current one is 13 days left as of the time of this writing -- you need 200 points per character, and there are three in the gacha)

Some of the characters are also only obtainable through the battle pass, such as All Might being locked at the highest level of the battle pass.

There are several different types of currencies which can be overwhelming.

My first instinct after the tutorial: check out the shop to see if heroes are currency locked, but I didn't find the heroes there, immediately checked on google how to unlock them, as you cannot buy them outright it seems. It was strangely confusing.

If you're planning to spend money on a small-scale battle royale game and are a big fan of MHA that you don't mind shelling out some cash for costumes and characters, dive in! Otherwise I would say hard pass, as other BRs are much better and more consumer-friendly than this one.
